solution_line_template: He consumed {total_drink_calories} calories, {sugar_percentage_drink_numerator}% of which is added sugar to give {total_drink_calories}*({sugar_percentage_drink_numerator}/{percentage_denominator}) = <<{total_drink_calories}*({sugar_percentage_drink_numerator}/{percentage_denominator})={sugar_from_drink}>>{sugar_from_drink} calories of added sugar.

He exceeded the recommended intake of {recommended_intake} calories by {exceed_percentage_numerator}% for a total consumption of {recommended_intake}+({recommended_intake}({exceed_percentage_numerator}/{percentage_denominator})) = $<<{recommended_intake}+({recommended_intake}*{exceed_percentage_numerator}/{percentage_denominator})={total_sugar_consumed}>>{total_sugar_consumed}
This means he took in {total_sugar_consumed}-{sugar_from_drink} = <<{total_sugar_consumed}-{sugar_from_drink}={sugar_from_candy}>>{sugar_from_candy} calories from candy alone

Each candy had {calories_per_bar} calories so {sugar_from_candy} calories which means he consumed {sugar_from_candy}/{calories_per_bar} = <<{sugar_from_candy}/{calories_per_bar}={number_of_bars}>>{number_of_bars} bars?
